{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3529319,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T01:37:58.349Z","cooked":"

We have been running into some issues with tuning our elevator. We are using a profiled PID controller on our cascade-rigged elevator powered by two NEOs. We are using WPILib’s elevator feedforward to compensate for the effect of gravity and to control velocity on the elevator. We have tuned the kG value of the feedforward so it keeps the elevator in place without moving and the kV value was determined by a mechanical design calculator.

Despite these measures we notice a significant difference when we command the elevator to travel down vs travel up. For example, we can tune the elevator to go from a down position to an up position to the point where it works near perfectly (quickly gets to setpoint without over shooting). However, if we then attempt to travel from a higher position to a lower position we get a either a significant over shoot or small, quick vibration-like oscillations (sorry I don’t have a video to share). Are these vibration-like oscillations caused by any other issue than incompatible PID gains? We have tried numerous PID gains, but none seem to work well for both upward and downward motion.

I believe the elevator feedforward should fix this sort of effect by compensating for the force of gravity. Is there something wrong with our implementation or our specific gains?

One idea we were going to try is using different PID gains for downward and upward motion. Could this solve our problem or this be a good idea?

Our elevator code can be found here: FRC-2648-2025/2025_robot_code/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Elevator.java at main · NoahLacks/FRC-2648-2025 · GitHub

Videos and/or telemetry plots would help greatly.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T01:43:24.212Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":561,"readers_count":560,"score":132.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/2","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529404,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T02:00:16.566Z","cooked":"

Unfortunately, I don’t have many videos to share that display this effect super well. Neither of these videos are of when we got our PID gains in a good state for upward or downward motion. In these videos when the elevator is traveling slowly I am controlling it manually, but when it goes fast to the center of the travel that is when the PID is triggered. The thing I wanted to highlight is that the speed/overshoot of the setpoint is larger when the PID goes from top to bottom vs bottom to top. I believe that is our key issue, but I would be interested if anyone else has other ideas.

I’ve observed a bouncy downward motion going down when kg is too high, and ks being not high enough.

I’m not an expert in system tunings (trust oblarg), but from observations in this condition, kg will hold it up, ks can’t help it move down, and you build up error on your PID; Once the error is large enough to exceed the excess kg and missing ks, it kicks the system into motion. This whole situation is unstable near the setpoint, which will lead to more cyclic bouncing as it drives the system against kg.

Can’t say for certain this is your issue, but your ks appears to be zero, and the kg is set to 0.7, next to a note about the calculated value being 0.6. So, maybe a starting point?

As for the bigger overshoots, I’d initially side eye your acceleration constraints; If that’s too high, then your system will only throw on the brakes after it’s too late to properly stop it at the setpoint.

Hi, rookie programmer here. How would you suggest going about feed forward tuning? We tried using sysID and got zeros for some of our values. Do you have a good method for tuning the feed forward manually? Or should we just run with the calculated values and see where ks brings us?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T02:50:29.721Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":444,"readers_count":443,"score":108.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"Noah LazerBeams","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52301,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, Driving, Singing"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/5","custom_user_title":"Programming, Driving, Singing","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529541,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T02:52:54.697Z","cooked":"

Interesting. So you think we should lower our kG and raise kS? We can certainly try that.

We can also try adjusting the acceleration constraints.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T02:52:54.697Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":423,"readers_count":422,"score":99.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53544,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, CAD"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/6","custom_user_title":"Programming, CAD","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529618,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T03:23:23.237Z","cooked":"

I’ve always let my programmers do the sysID work, so can’t help there. When I have questions, I ask one of them, or read Oblarg’s post history; Someone on CD has had that question, and oblarg has probably answered it.

For ks and kg values, they’re easy enough to get experimentally; Just hold the system stable and stationary, and slowly increase output until it moves up. Write that down.
Get it stable again, decrease output until it moves down. kS is the difference divided by two, and the average is kg.

kA and kV are trickier to guess by hand, but when in doubt… zero works. That’ll let the system operate under stability, and you can figure them out in a performance tuning pass later.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T03:24:17.712Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":407,"readers_count":406,"score":241.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/7","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529626,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T03:29:08.321Z","cooked":"

Okay that helps. We got those our kG value by just measuring when it begins going up. We never found when it begins to go down and finding the difference divided by two. That is something to try.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T03:29:08.321Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":373,"readers_count":372,"score":79.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53544,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, CAD"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/8","custom_user_title":"Programming, CAD","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529628,"name":"Noah LazerBeams","username":"NoahLacks","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/noahlacks/{size}/250843_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T03:29:50.074Z","cooked":"

Just to clarify:

kG Too high - kG too low / 2 = kS

kG too high + kG too low / 2 = kG

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T03:29:50.074Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":363,"readers_count":362,"score":122.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"Noah LazerBeams","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52301,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, Driving, Singing"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/9","custom_user_title":"Programming, Driving, Singing","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529647,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T03:37:49.444Z","cooked":"

To be precise:
( (value that goes up) - (value that goes down) )/ 2 = ks
( (value that goes up) + (value that goes down) )/2 = kg

The idea here is that kg is the output that results in no motion; It counteracts the force applied by gravity.

ks is the value added to that that barely generates motion; It models the friction and other overcoming of inertia.
So, when finding this experimentally, you’ll probably get a ks slightly too high, and it’ll have a minor rapid oscillation. In that case, just lower it a bit. I find (experimental ks)*0.8 tends to work well enough.

We got those our kG value by just measuring when it begins going up.

If that’s how you determined it, this explains some of the issue: This would result in a “kg” that’s kg+ks; So when going down, you’re off by a factor of 2*ks.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T03:37:49.444Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":23,"reads":358,"readers_count":357,"score":301.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52301,"username":"NoahLacks","name":"Noah LazerBeams","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/noahlacks/{size}/250843_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/10","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529770,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T04:24:47.666Z","cooked":"
NoahLacks:

Hi, rookie programmer here. How would you suggest going about feed forward tuning? We tried using sysID and got zeros for some of our values. Do you have a good method for tuning the feed forward manually? Or should we just run with the calculated values and see where ks brings us?

You should always be able to check feedforward values via hand calculations, and these hand calculations are quite accurate. kG needs to oppose the elevator weight, while kV needs to oppose the back-emf (and a tiny bit of viscous friction, but like 95% back-emf), both of which can be calculated by hand. For a NEO, kV should be .01965 V-s/rad in the motor’s frame of reference, while kG should be .01957A * the effective weight of the elevator in N-m, again at the motor’s frame of reference.

As for hand-tuning kG, you should set it such that the elevator is equally easy to move up and down. Just because the elevator isn’t moving doesn’t mean your kG is correct, dry friction is a thing.

tekdemo:

ks is the value added to that that barely generates motion; It models the friction and other overcoming of inertia.

I’ve had better luck tuning kS to oppose kinetic friction instead of dry friction. During transient behavior, a controller is always moving, therefore, you want to oppose kinetic friction, as the rest of the gains will break static friction almost immediately. The kinetic friction value is also the value that you’d get out of curve-fitting to a quasi-static test or unexpected static gains on a frequency response.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T04:54:26.604Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":281,"readers_count":280,"score":66.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48664,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5503"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/13","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5503","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529800,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T05:36:00.385Z","cooked":"

Those are more advanced that where you are now, so don’t sweat the deep details on that yet. Loop back around as you gain understanding in the process. But, I’ll try to sum up to help you out.

“back emf” stems from the fact that a motor and a generator are basically the same physical construction, but tuned for different roles. A system in motion is also generating power, which is flowing backward through your motor. This opposes the motion, proportionally to the speed at which it’s moving. The units help: Volts*seconds/radian. Contrast that to rotational velocity of radian/second and you can see kinda how it’s correlating the voltage and rotation.
Because this is a predictable value, defined by the motor’s construction… you can model it in your feed forward.

The kinetic friction value is also the value that you’d get out of curve-fitting to a quasi-static test or unexpected static gains on a frequency response.

In case this part tripped you up, this is referring to the fact that there’s two types of friction, which are best described as the minimum force required to make a system start moving, and the force required to keep it moving at a constant speed.

This is more precise correct than my reply, but also not quite you’re actually testing with the basic setup I described, which gives you voltage to overcome static friction. Since dynamic friction is always lower than static, reducing the resulting kS gain gets you closer to this actual desired value.

If you check the SysID output, you’ll probably be able to see on some of the graphs, it’s presenting this data as described. The tooling plots this value over time, and tries to generate the correct kS value using calculations through the motion.

This type of clarification was probably pointed at me, since I could have described it better and more precisely. Just like you guys I’m still learning the depths of motor control theory, but just have more background to help break it down.

I liked tek demo’s response

Glad it’s helping you out.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":67,"updated_at":"2025-02-17T06:19:37.531Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":244,"readers_count":243,"score":53.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":491991,"topic_slug":"elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52301,"username":"NoahLacks","name":"Noah LazerBeams","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/noahlacks/{size}/250843_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53544,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, CAD"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-pid-tuning-issues-with-gravity/491991/16","custom_user_title":"Programming, CAD","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529838,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T09:43:45.179Z","cooked":"

Your Elevator Constants file gives a maximum calculated speed of 184 inches per second and a kFeedforwardV of .12.
The units of kv are Volts per whatever speed units you have. So if the control asks for 100 inches per second, feedforward will apply 100 *kv volts.
The product of these 2 numbers can’t exceed the battery voltage. Currently it is 22.08. So you are telling the motor to go almost twice as fast as you should be.

A good starting approximation for Kv is 12/max speed - in your case 12/184 = .06
The earlier post gave “For a NEO, kV should be .01965 V-s/rad” or multiplying by 2PI =.12 Volts per rev per second.
NEOs do approximately 100 revs per second and *.12=12 volts.
Your position conversion factor is around 2 so .12/2 = .06

You have ks at 0 meaning if takes no extra volts to get it started and kg at .7 meaning it takes .7 volts to hold it in place against gravity.
We usually have a jog command for an elevator using a gamepad stick. It allows measuring of ks and kg by reading back the motor applied output * battery volts.

You already have it! Its your runManualElevator which you have as your default command already, using your codriver gamepad.

To see the voltage being applied to the motor add this to the ElevatorSubsystem periodic() method.
double volts =elevatorMotor1.getAppliedOutput()*RobotController.getBatteryVoltage();
SmartDashboard.putNumber(“ELevatorVolts”,volts);
You can observe this on AdvantageScope or Elastic or any of the available dashboards.
To determine ks, slowly increase your stick until the elevator just starts to move. The voltage you see at that point is ks.
To determine kg, raise the elevator using the gamepad stick.
At a convenient point, adjust the stick until the elevator just holds its position without falling. The voltage you need to do this is your kG value.
You could also usefully add SmartDashboard entries for elevator position and current.

icemannie:

To determine ks, slowly increase your stick until the elevator just starts to move. The voltage you see at that point is ks.

You mean, kG plus kS, assuming it started moving upwards.
